## 판결문 요약


660 S.W.2d 55 (1983)
James W. CROUCHER, Jr. et al., Petitioners,
v.
Virginia M. CROUCHER, Respondent.
No. C-1855.
Supreme Court of Texas.
November 2, 1983.
Rehearing Denied December 14, 1983.
*56 Ken Powell, El Paso, for petitioners.
James T. Allen, El Paso, for respondent.
SPEARS, Justice.
This case involves a will contest. James Croucher Sr. died in 1980, leaving a self-proving will devising his entire estate to his wife, respondent Virginia Croucher. Petitioners James Croucher Jr. and Kenneth Croucher, Mr. Croucher's sons by a previous marriage, contested the will, alleging that their father did not have testamentary capacity. Based on a jury finding that Mr. Croucher lacked such capacity, the trial court rendered judgment that the will be denied probate. The Court of Appeals reversed, holding that the evidence established as a matter of law that Mr. Croucher had testamentary capacity. We reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals and affirm that of the trial court.
The evidence shows that Mr. Croucher had a history of physical problems, many of which stemmed from his being diabetic. In December 1979, he was admitted to the hospital to have two toes amputated. A brain scan done at that time indicated that Mr. Croucher had a diminished flow of blood to the brain in the right carotid artery.
